executive_summary: The Cemetery Services industry provides products and services for bereaved family members of the deceased, which may include sales of family plots, mausoleums, memorials and columbaria, in addition to sales of merchandise, including urns and ornamental goods. The industry sells services on either a pre-need (sold before death) or at-need (sold following a death) basis.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Aging Population Benefits the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The number of US deaths is the predominant driver for the industry. The rapidly growing and aging population will increase deaths in the future. The number of deaths has risen over the past five years, partly because of the changing age structure of the population, which is becoming increasingly concentrated among elderly citizens.

With improving economic conditions, families have become less price-conscious and increased their purchases of certain high-profit funeral merchandise and services. In particular, cemetery service operators started expanding the array of merchandise items offered to families who choose cremation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Cremations Have Risen in Popularity Among Customers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cremation services have become increasingly more popular than traditional burials. Cremations can also be as little as one-third the cost of burials. Periods of economic declines, such as during the COVID-19 pandemic, exacerbated this trend since families are more likely to choose inexpensive options and forego purchasing any additional industry products or services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry's Most Significant Players Expand Operations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry's largest companies steadily consolidated in recent years, partially led by increasing merger and acquisition activity. Larger companies, including Service Corporation International (Service Corp.) and StoneMor Partners LP (StoneMor), exhibited strong merger and acquisition activity and routinely purchased smaller cemetery service providers during the current five-year period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Disposable Income and Consumer Spending Helped
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As disposable income and consumer spending are forecast to increase throughout 2024, consumers will be more inclined to purchase more upsell products and services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: AN AGING POPULATION WILL BOOST DEMAND FOR CEMETERY SERVICES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The nature of the industry makes it rare for cemeteries to encounter rapid revenue growth, although the changing age structure of the US population will provide steady revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE TREND TOWARD CREMATION WILL CONTINUE TO BE PREVALENT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although people will have more money to spend on burials, cremation will continue to become more prevalent over the next five years. Cremations cost much less than a traditional burial, making them more attractive to customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A CHANGING LANDSCAPE WILL IMPROVE MARKET SHARE FOR LARGER COMPANIES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increased merger and acquisition activity is expected to continue among the industry's largest operators during the period. As the trend toward cremations threatens to limit revenue gains, major companies will increasingly acquire regional operators to increase customer bases.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Disposable Income and Consumer Spending Will Continue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As disposable incomes rise, families will purchase specialized services and merchandise for burials and forego direct cremation services, often purchased because of the families' inability to afford costlier cemetery products and services.

industry_definition: This industry includes establishments that operate sites or structures reserved for the interment of human or animal remains. The industry also includes companies that offer cremation services. This industry does not include funeral homes, even those that operate cemeteries; these companies are included in the Funeral Homes industry (IBISWorld report 81221).

opportunities: Number of adults aged 65 and older

key_trends: Cremations are significantly less expensive than traditional burials, resulting in cremations rising in popularity over the past five years.

An aging population will benefit the industry during the outlook period. Also, as disposable income rises, families will be encouraged to purchase specialized services and merchandise for burials, boosting industry revenue.

State cooling-off legislation is in place concerning the sale of preneed cemetery contracts. Cooling-off legislation typically requires operators to refund proceeds from contracts for any reason within three to 30 days.

Industry associations provide support to the industry. Associations assist the industry with finances, improving federal funding to maintain national cemeteries and funding to preserve historic properties.

Cremation services have grown because they are less expensive than burials. Environmental concerns and a growing preference for simple services have also contributed to greater demand for cremation services.

As the baby-boomer generation moves into retirement age, it will continue to encompass a significant share of the overall US population. The industry will benefit since most of its pre-need and at-need services are purchased by this demographic.

The distribution of cemeteries and crematories is related to population trends and age structure. Consumer preferences for cremation, as opposed to burials, are another important factor that can influence the share of establishments.

market_segmentation.segment_description: People older than 75 make up an increasingly large share of the population; this trend is expected to continue over the next five years, increasing demand for cemetery services. This market segment accounts for over half of revenue. Heart disease and cancer are the leading causes of death for people older than 75 years old.

The second-largest market comprises adults between 55 and 74 years old, who make up more than a third of total deaths. Heart disease and cancer are the leading causes of death for this age group. Pre-need sales represent an opportunity for operator expansion because the target market is larger.

Adults between 35 and 54 years old make up the third-largest market. Car accidents, suicides and cancer are the leading causes of death among this age group. This group typically requires at-need services more than pre-need services. This market segment has declined over the last five years.
Persons between 15 and 34 years old make up the fourth-largest market for the industry. Car accidents, suicides and cancer are the leading causes of death among this age group.

The smallest market for cemetery services is people aged 14 and younger. Leading causes include congenital disabilities for those under one-year-old and accidental causes, which are statistically more likely to come from car accidents and drowning within this demographic.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Sale of graves, plots and other spaces
products_and_services.product_description: The Cemetery Services industry derives most of its revenue from selling plots, graves or spaces in mausoleums. Typically, a funeral home will negotiate the purchase of burial plots, though consumers can do this on an individual basis.
Cemeteries will typically offer sales of caskets, urns and other memorial markers, including headstones, commemorative plaques, mausoleums, vaults and liners.

Interment services represent a substantial source of revenue for the industry. These services include preparing plots and gravesites for services or burial. Interment services include placing ashes in niches, mausoleums and other similar facilities.

Pre-burial services vary depending on whether the end service is a burial or a cremation. If relatives or the deceased have chosen a burial, the body is typically washed and disinfected before burial.

Cemetery maintenance services are a small but stable source of revenue for the industry. These services include allocating land for burial, digging graves, maintaining the grounds and performing basic landscaping services.

Direct cremation involves transporting the deceased to the crematory, cremating the body and returning the remains to the family quickly. Traditional cremation can be as elaborate as a traditional burial service and include a visitation service before the cremation, funeral or memorial service.
Cemetery operators may sell commemorative items, books, cards, videos, photographs and other memorial items and these products typically generate high profits.

tier_1_suppliers: Surveying & Mapping Services in the US
Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Plant & Flower Growing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Florida is an attractive destination for retirement-aged adults
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Florida is an attractive destination for retirement-aged adults. This has driven the Southeast region's share of industry establishments.
Industry services depend on consumer preferences. Cremations have become a popular choice for consumers in recent years.
Operators rely on client-family relationships and referrals fostered at the local level. Relationships at the local level help build trust in the community, driving business.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the most significant share of cemeteries in the United States, accounting for almost one-quarter of establishments. Florida is a very attractive destination for retirement-aged adults because of the state's warm weather and affordable housing. Population density in this area has been rising for the past decade, making the region attractive for operators. Consumers within this region prefer traditional burial services, as opposed to direct cremations, making the region more lucrative for the industry.

The Mid-Atlantic has the second-highest share of industry establishments, accounting for almost a quarter of establishments as well but slightly less than the Southeast. Pennsylvania is the most heavily concentrated state in the country regarding industry establishments. New York contains the second-highest number of establishments in the country. This is because New York has one of the highest population levels and is one of the most densely populated states in the United States.
Within this region, Ohio contains the most cemeteries and crematories. A more significant share of the population is older than 65 in the region compared to the national average.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Most states have cooling-off legislation concerning the sale of preneed cemetery contracts. Legislation typically requires operators to refund proceeds from contracts for any reason within three to 30 days, though in certain states, this period may be extended. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) also requires a cooling-off period of three business days for door-to-door sales. A contract may be canceled, resulting in customers being entitled to a refund.

H.R. 3655 directs the FTC to extend the Funeral Rule to cemeteries, crematories and casket sellers. The Funeral Rule requires providers to give consumers accurate, itemized price information about goods and services and prohibits funeral providers from misrepresenting legal, crematory and cemetery requirements; embalming for a fee without permission; requiring the purchase of a casket for a direct cremation; or requiring consumers to buy goods or services tied with funerals.

Laws such as the Clean Air Act regulate emissions into the air and enact emission control requirements for crematory operations. The Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act require operators to maintain and submit to authorities' inventories of hazardous materials at industry establishments. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act imposes remediation obligations for threatened or actual releases of hazardous substances that could endanger public health, welfare or the environment.

Many state governments have enacted preservation funds in the form of trusts. These trusts collect contributions and can be used to maintain the public areas of a cemetery, although not necessarily to upkeep the areas near individual graves. These funds aim to ensure that the upkeep of cemeteries and the interred are respected and maintained even after the cemeteries' revenue-generating years have passed.

basis_points.basis_description: Industry services depend on consumer preferences.
Cremations have become a popular choice for consumers in recent years.
Operators rely on client-family relationships and referrals fostered at the local level.
Relationships at the local level help build trust in the community, driving business.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Majority of companies are small and locally based
concentration_points.concentration_description: The majority of companies are small and locally based

concentration_points.concentration_title: Companies operate one cemetery or crematory
concentration_points.concentration_description: The majority of companies are small and operate just one cemetery or crematory.
Companies are almost entirely local, with most cemeteries serving customers that live within a 10- to 15-mile radius of the property's location.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation expenses remain stable and are mainly associated with property and maintenance equipment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation expenses have remained relatively stable over the past five years. Newer cemeteries have high fixed costs related to building columbaria and setting up crematories. Cemetery and crematory operators must invest in cemetery property and maintenance equipment, representing significant depreciation costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: OTHER MISCELLANEOUS COSTS ARE HIGH AS THE UPKEEP OF CEMETERIES IS VIEWED AS NECESSARY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Miscellaneous expenses include sales and administrative expenses, restructuring, legal, goodwill adjustments and others. This segment accounts for the largest cost for the cemetery industry and has remained stable over the past five years. Many state governments enacted preservations that collect from cemetery contributions to ensure that the upkeep of cemeteries and the interred are respected and maintained even after the cemeteries' revenue-generating years have passed.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGES EMPLOYEES ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DAY-TO-DAY TASKS, KEEPING WAGES AS THE MOST SIGNIFICANT EXPENSE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are the second most significant expense for the industry and have declined over the past five years. Employees are essential for customer service roles, management, administration, maintenance, landscaping and preparing burial plots and niches. Although the total value of wages has declined throughout 2024, the total average salary has increased as skilled employees are vital for operations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Labor is critical to the industry
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor is critical to the industry. Employees are necessary for customer service roles, management, administration, maintenance, landscaping and preparing burial plots and niches.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and concentration of patents
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The number of deaths is the primary driver of volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The number of deaths in the United States does not undergo significant volatility, resulting in a moderate level of volatility for the industry. Over the past five years, the number of deaths has increased along with industry revenue.

Changes in population demographics can affect the industry. As the population ages, the industry may encounter an increase in the services demanded. Economic downturns may result in individuals spending less on funeral and burial services.

FAQs.question: What percent of revenue is assigned to advertising?
FAQs.answer: Typically, cemetery service companies allocate a small percentage of revenue to marketing.

FAQs.question: INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE
FAQs.answer: THE INDUSTRY RECEIVES MINIMAL INDUSTRY-SPECIFIC PROTECTION IN THE FORM OF FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIES

FAQs.question: INDUSTRY ASSOCIATIONS
FAQs.answer: The Funeral Consumers Alliance provides information to consumers on how to organize end-of-life care and finances. The industry indirectly benefits from the public policy initiatives set forth by veteran organizations, which often seek to improve federal funding to preserve and maintain national, municipal and commercial cemeteries. The National Historic Preservation Act provides funding to preserve historic properties, sites, buildings and objects listed on the National Register of historic places.

FAQs.question: Do you market your company's services on e-commerce sites, such as Groupon, to generate sales?
FAQs.answer: Improving visibility online can help your company generate new customers.

FAQs.question: How does your company competitively price your services in areas where similar services are widely available?
FAQs.answer: Attracting customers based on price can increase your company's market share.

FAQs.question: Is your company conveniently located in high-traffic areas to maximize visibility?
FAQs.answer: Locating your company on a major road can improve local visibility.

FAQs.question: What data analytic programs does your company use to track company-wide sales?
FAQs.answer: Tracking sales using analytic programs can help a company evaluate its financial performance and make necessary adjustments.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage social media platforms, such as Facebook, Twitter and Yelp, to establish a stronger market presence?
FAQs.answer: Establishing an online presence with reviews makes a company more credible and trustworthy when a potential consumer is looking for cemetery services.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly affected profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Staying ahead of potential regulatory changes can help reduce compliance costs.

FAQs.question: Is your company exempt from sales tax and property taxes in certain states?
FAQs.answer: Establishing operations in states with low taxation can improve a company's financial performance.

FAQs.question: How do your wage expenses compare to an average operator?
FAQs.answer: Wages are a significant expense for the industry, consuming nearly a third of total expenses.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: The average profit margin for a company in this industry is around 9%.

FAQs.question: How much do you spend on routine maintenance? How do you ensure that your maintenance is both adequate and cost-effective?
FAQs.answer: Carrying out all necessary maintenance to keep facilities in good condition. Aesthetic appeal is one of the primary factors that individuals consider when choosing a cemetery.

FAQs.question: What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area? Do you have a competitive pricing strategy?
FAQs.answer: Establishments that are located close to or within a major city or town will gain a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in government regulations?
Have you had any issues with government regulations in the past?
FAQs.answer: Complying with all government regulations is a necessity for industry operators.

FAQs.question: How have you been affected by increasing demand for cremations in recent years? How can you yield more growth from this segment?
FAQs.answer: Since cremations bring in significantly less revenue and profit for cemeteries, rising demand for cremations has adversely affected the industry.

FAQs.question: How will you market to this age group as the elderly population expands? Do you investigate and act upon generational preferences and trends?
FAQs.answer: This age segment of the population accounts for the majority of all deaths; therefore, this driver is positively correlated to industry performance.

FAQs.question: What tiers of service or quality do you offer? What is your most popular service offering?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income is high, families are more likely to purchase additional industry merchandise and services, which favorably affects revenue.
